metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, PHP, Python, Bootstrap, Java and XML.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: DSA Merge Sort Time Complexity
See this page for a general explanation of what time complexity is.
content.html: See this page for a general explanation of what time complexity is.

content.text: Merge Sort Time Complexity
The Merge Sort algorithm breaks the array down into smaller and smaller pieces.
content.html: The Merge Sort algorithm breaks the array down into smaller and smaller pieces.

content.text: The array becomes sorted when the sub-arrays are merged back together so that the lowest values come first.
content.html: The array becomes sorted when the sub-arrays are merged back together so that the lowest values come first.

content.text: The array that needs to be sorted has n n values, and we can find the time complexity by start looking at the number of operations needed by the algorithm.
content.html: The array that needs to be sorted has nn values, and we can find the time complexity by start looking at the number of operations needed by the algorithm.

content.text: The main operations Merge Sort does is to split, and then merge by comparing elements.
content.html: The main operations Merge Sort does is to split, and then merge by comparing elements.

content.text: To split an array from start until the sub-arrays only consists of one value, Merge Sort does a total of n − 1 n − 1 splits. Just imaging an array with 16 values. It is split one time into sub-arrays of length 8, split again and again, and the size of the sub-arrays reduces to 4, 2 and finally 1. The number of splits for an array of 16 elements is 1 + 2 + 4 + 8 = 15 1 + 2 + 4 + 8 = 15 .
content.html: To split an array from start until the sub-arrays only consists of one value, Merge Sort does a total of n−1n−1 splits. Just imaging an array with 16 values. It is split one time into sub-arrays of length 8, split again and again, and the size of the sub-arrays reduces to 4, 2 and finally 1. The number of splits for an array of 16 elements is 1+2+4+8=151+2+4+8=15.

content.text: The image below shows that 15 splits are needed for an array of 16 numbers.
content.html: The image below shows that 15 splits are needed for an array of 16 numbers.

content.text: The number of merges is actually also n − 1 n − 1 , the same as the number of splits, because every split needs a merge to build the array back together. And for each merge there is a comparison between values in the sub-arrays so that the merged result is sorted.
content.html: The number of merges is actually also n−1n−1, the same as the number of splits, because every split needs a merge to build the array back together. And for each merge there is a comparison between values in the sub-arrays so that the merged result is sorted.

content.text: During merging of two sub-arrays, the worst case scenario that generates the most comparisons, is if the sub-arrays are equally big. Just consider merging [1,4,6,9] and [2,3,7,8]. In this case the following comparisons are needed:
content.html: During merging of two sub-arrays, the worst case scenario that generates the most comparisons, is if the sub-arrays are equally big. Just consider merging [1,4,6,9] and [2,3,7,8]. In this case the following comparisons are needed:

content.text: At the end of the merge, only the value 9 is left in one array, the other array is empty, so no comparison is needed to put the last value in, and the resulting merged array is [1,2,3,4,6,7,8,9]. We see that we need 7 comparisons to merge 8 values (4 values in each of the initial sub-arrays). In general, in a worst case scenario, n − 1 n − 1 comparisons are needed to get a merged array of n n values.
content.html: At the end of the merge, only the value 9 is left in one array, the other array is empty, so no comparison is needed to put the last value in, and the resulting merged array is [1,2,3,4,6,7,8,9]. We see that we need 7 comparisons to merge 8 values (4 values in each of the initial sub-arrays). In general, in a worst case scenario, n−1n−1 comparisons are needed to get a merged array of nn values.

content.text: For simplicity, let's say that we need n n comparisons instead of n − 1 n − 1 when merging n n values. This is an ok assumption when n n is large and we want to calculate an upper bound using Big O notation.
content.html: For simplicity, let's say that we need nn comparisons instead of n−1n−1 when merging nn values. This is an ok assumption when nn is large and we want to calculate an upper bound using Big O notation.

content.text: So, at each level merging happens, n n comparisons are needed, but how many levels are there? Well, for n = 16 n = 16 we have n = 16 = 2 4 n = 16 = 2 4 , so 4 levels of merging. For n = 32 = 2 5 n = 32 = 2 5 there are 5 levels of merging, and at each level, n n comparisons are needed. For n = 1024 = 2 10 n = 1024 = 2 10 10 levels of merging is needed. To find out what power of 2 gives us 1024, we use a base-2 logarithm. The answer is 10. Mathematically it looks like this: log 2 1024 = 10 log 2 ⁡ 1024 = 10 .
content.html: So, at each level merging happens, nn comparisons are needed, but how many levels are there? Well, for n=16n=16 we have n=16=24n=16=24, so 4 levels of merging. For n=32=25n=32=25 there are 5 levels of merging, and at each level, nn comparisons are needed. For n=1024=210n=1024=210 10 levels of merging is needed. To find out what power of 2 gives us 1024, we use a base-2 logarithm. The answer is 10. Mathematically it looks like this: log21024=10log2⁡1024=10.

content.text: As we can see from the figure above, n n comparisons are needed on each level, and there are log 2 n log 2 ⁡ n levels, so there are n ⋅ log 2 n n ⋅ log 2 ⁡ n comparison operations in total.
content.html: As we can see from the figure above, nn comparisons are needed on each level, and there are log2nlog2⁡n levels, so there are n⋅log2nn⋅log2⁡n comparison operations in total.

content.text: Time complexity can be calculated based on the number of split operations and the number of merge operations:
content.html: Time complexity can be calculated based on the number of split operations and the number of merge operations:

content.text: O ( ( n − 1 ) + n ⋅ log 2 n ) = O ( n ⋅ log 2 n ) O ( ( n − 1 ) + n ⋅ log 2 ⁡ n ) = O ( n ⋅ log 2 ⁡ n )
content.html: O((n−1)+n⋅log2n)=O(n⋅log2n)O((n−1)+n⋅log2⁡n)=O(n⋅log2⁡n)

content.text: The number of splitting operations ( n − 1 ) ( n − 1 ) can be removed from the Big O calculation above because n ⋅ log 2 n n ⋅ log 2 ⁡ n will dominate for large n n , and because of how we calculate time complexity for algorithms.
content.html: The number of splitting operations (n−1)(n−1) can be removed from the Big O calculation above because n⋅log2nn⋅log2⁡n will dominate for large nn, and because of how we calculate time complexity for algorithms.

content.text: The figure below shows how the time increases when running Merge Sort on an array with n n values.
content.html: The figure below shows how the time increases when running Merge Sort on an array with nn values.

content.text: The difference between best and worst case scenarios for Merge Sort is not as big as for many other sorting algorithms.
content.html: The difference between best and worst case scenarios for Merge Sort is not as big as for many other sorting algorithms.

content.text: Merge Sort Simulation
Run the simulation for different number of values in an array, and see how the number of operations Merge Sort needs on an array of n n elements is O ( n log n ) O ( n log ⁡ n ) :
content.html: Run the simulation for different number of values in an array, and see how the number of operations Merge Sort needs on an array of nn elements is O(nlogn)O(nlog⁡n):

content.text: Set values: 300
content.html: 300

content.text: Random
Descending
Ascending
10 Random
Operations: 0
content.html: Operations: 0

content.text: If we hold the number of values n n fixed, the number of operations needed for the "Random", "Descending" and "Ascending" is almost the same.
content.html: If we hold the number of values nn fixed, the number of operations needed for the "Random", "Descending" and "Ascending" is almost the same.

content.text: Merge Sort performs almost the same every time because the array is split, and merged using comparison, both if the array is already sorted or not.
content.html: Merge Sort performs almost the same every time because the array is split, and merged using comparison, both if the array is already sorted or not.
